title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0001
text: What is the main purpose of an Anti-Corruption Layer (ACL) in microservices refactoring?

options.text: To isolate a new microservice from legacy system dependencies
To merge legacy and new systems directly
To replace the legacy system entirely
To store data for both systems

explanation: An Anti-Corruption Layer isolates new microservices from legacy systems, preventing direct dependency and model corruption.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0002
text: Which design pattern does the Anti-Corruption Layer concept originate from?
explanation: The Anti-Corruption Layer concept originates from Domain-Driven Design (DDD) to protect domain models from external influence.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0003
text: What problem does an Anti-Corruption Layer primarily solve?

options.text: Model corruption due to direct integration with legacy systems

explanation: An ACL prevents model corruption by avoiding direct integration between new and legacy systems.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0004
text: Which of the following best describes the function of an Anti-Corruption Layer?

options.text: It translates and adapts communication between systems
It stores data for both systems

explanation: An ACL acts as a translator and adapter between systems, ensuring model and data consistency.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0005
text: What is a key benefit of using an Anti-Corruption Layer?

options.text: It prevents legacy system complexity from leaking into new services
It eliminates the need for testing

explanation: An ACL prevents legacy complexity from leaking into new microservices by isolating and translating interactions.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0006
text: Which of the following components are typically part of an Anti-Corruption Layer?
explanation: An ACL typically includes adapters, translators, and facades to mediate between systems.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0007
text: In which scenario is an Anti-Corruption Layer most useful?

options.text: When integrating a new microservice with a legacy system

explanation: An ACL is most useful when integrating new microservices with legacy systems to prevent model contamination.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0008
text: What is the main risk of not using an Anti-Corruption Layer during migration?

options.text: The new system becomes tightly coupled to the legacy system

explanation: Without an ACL, the new system can become tightly coupled to the legacy system, inheriting its complexity.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0009
text: Which of the following best describes the communication flow with an Anti-Corruption Layer?
explanation: The ACL sits between the new service and the legacy system, mediating all communication.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0010
text: Which of the following is a key principle of the Anti-Corruption Layer?
explanation: The ACL translates between different domain models to maintain separation and integrity.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0011
text: Which of the following is a benefit of using an Anti-Corruption Layer for maintainability?

options.text: Simplifies maintenance by isolating legacy dependencies

explanation: An ACL simplifies maintenance by isolating legacy dependencies and reducing coupling.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0012
text: Which of the following is a benefit of using an Anti-Corruption Layer for testing?

options.text: Allows testing of new services independently from legacy systems
Requires testing the entire system at once

explanation: An ACL allows independent testing of new services without affecting the legacy system.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0013
text: Which of the following is a benefit of using an Anti-Corruption Layer for risk reduction?

options.text: Reduces risk by decoupling new and old systems

explanation: The ACL reduces risk by decoupling new and old systems, allowing safe incremental migration.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0014
text: Which of the following is a benefit of using an Anti-Corruption Layer for scalability?

options.text: New services can scale independently of legacy systems
Scaling requires redeploying the entire system
Scaling is limited to the database

explanation: An ACL allows new services to scale independently, improving flexibility and performance.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0015
text: Which of the following is a benefit of using an Anti-Corruption Layer for agility?

options.text: Enables faster delivery of new features

explanation: An ACL enables faster delivery of new features by allowing independent development of new services.

options.text: Failures in the legacy system do not affect new services

explanation: An ACL improves fault isolation by preventing failures in the legacy system from affecting new services.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0017

options.text: Allows independent evolution of new services

explanation: An ACL allows independent evolution of new services without being constrained by legacy systems.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringAntiCorruptionLayer - Q0018

options.text: Each new service can recover independently

explanation: An ACL improves resilience by allowing independent recovery of new services.
